Copper clusters supported on TiO2 have demonstrated exceptional performance in catalyzing the reduction of CO2. However, there is a lack of detailed studies on the underlying mechanism. In this study, we employ first-principles thermodynamics and kinetic calculations to unveil the catalytic reduction mechanism of CO2 to C1 product on the Cu5/TiO2 catalyst. Our calculations reveal that the interaction between the cluster and the support significantly enhances the chemical adsorption of CO2 and lowers the dissociation barrier of H2, creating favorable conditions for hydrogenation reduction of CO2. Additionally, our findings suggest that the Cu5 cluster also significantly enhances the adsorption of *CO intermediates, resulting in a preference for the RWGS pathway over the formate pathway for CO2 reduction. The rate-determining barrier for CH3OH formation is considerably lower than that for CH4 formation, indicating that Cu5/TiO2 exhibits remarkable CO2 conversion performance with nearly 100 % selectivity towards CH3OH production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Copper clusters TiO2 surface Co2 reduction Mechanism Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Rapid industrial development has resulted in significant carbon dioxide emissions, which contribute to the greenhouse effect and have caused various environmental issues such as glacier melting and ocean acidification. Addressing global warming and energy depletion requires a reduction in carbon dioxide emissions [1-4]. Therefore, artificial carbon conversion technologies like thermocatalytic reduction, photocatalytic reduction, and electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 [5] hold practical significance. Photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction and electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction are more viable and cost-effective methods for converting CO2 compared to thermal catalysis due to their utilization of renewable energy sources at room temperature [6-8]. In the field of photocatalytic and electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, copper demonstrates unique properties in converting CO2 to hydrocarbon fuels. Despite being a non-precious transition metal, copper is widely regarded as the most reliable metallic material for catalyzing CO2 into multi-carbon products [9-11]. Among various Cu-based catalyst materials, both Cu single-atom catalysts (SACs) and small-sized Cu single-cluster catalysts (SCCs) have emerged as prominent areas of research. Highly-dispersed individual atoms or small clusters of copper possess distinct electronic structures compared to bulk materials, [12] resulting in enhanced catalytic activities [13-15]. For instance, Zu et al. [16] conducted a study on the catalytic reduction of CO2 using Cu-based metal-organic framework (MOF) structures. The findings revealed that *COOH intermediate can be readily formed, leading to an almost 100 % selectivity for CO. Compared to Cu-SACs, Cu-SCC exhibits superior stability, which has sparked increased research interest. Zang et al. [17] synthesized various structural ligand-coated Cu8 cluster and investigated their electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance. The experiment revealed that the ditetrahedral-shaped Cu8 cluster demonstrated better catalytic CO2 reduction performance than the cubic-shaped cluster, with a high Faraday efficiency of 92 % for HCOOH generation. Liu et al. [18] explored the mechanism of catalytic reduction of CO2 by Cu4 clusters loaded on Al2O3. They observed that, in comparison to larger-sized Cu clusters and Cu nanoparticles, the Cu4 clusters exhibited a lower rate-limiting potential barrier and good CH3OH selectivity. Among all small-sized Cun clusters, both isolated and supported Cu5 clusters displayed particular structural stability [19-21]. Lara-Castells et al. [22,23] investigated the photocatalytic properties of TiO2-supported Cu5 cluster for CO2 decomposition using density functional calculations. They found that loading stable Cu5 clusters could prolong the lifetime of photo-induced carriers, enhance the visible-light response of TiO2, improve CO2 adsorption, and significantly reduce its decomposition barrier. Although the TiO2-supported Cu5 cluster may exhibit significant catalytic performance in CO2 reduction, a comprehensive and thorough investigation of the mechanism is currently lacking. Due to the potential formation of multiple products during CO2 reduction on Cu-based catalysts, understanding the mechanism pathways is crucial for enhancing the activity and selectivity of these catalysts. In this study, we conducted a comprehensive examination of the mechanism involved in the CO2 reduction reaction on the anatase TiO2-supported Cu5 cluster. We investigated CO2 adsorption, H2 dissociation and H migration, as well as different pathways for CO2 reduction in detail. Our results demonstrate that CO2 can chemically adsorb onto Cu5/TiO2. Additionally, H2 can be easily dissociated as a proton source, with the resulting protons migrating readily on both the Cu5 cluster and TiO2 surface. The *CO2 can be easily activated and reduced into *CO via the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction. The binding of Cu5 to *CO is strong, ensuring subsequent hydrogenation reactions. Furthermore, our findings indicate good selectivity in the reduction products, with CH3OH being identified as the most likely final product. 2 Computational details All calculations are performed by using the first-principles method implemented in the VASP 5.4 package [24,25]. The Perdew-Burke-Enzerhof (PBE)[26] exchange–correlation functional within the generalized gradient approximation, and the projector augment wave (PAW) pseudopotentials with the valence configurations of 2s22p4 for O, 2p63d24s2 for Ti and 3d104s1 for Cu are adopted. The CI-NEB [27] and dimer method [28] are used to search for the transition state of each reaction step. An cutoff energy of 400 eV for the plane wave functions and single Γ point for the K-sampling are selected in the structural relaxation, CI-NEB and dimer calculations. The energies of the optimized stable and transition state structures are computed by using a higher energy cutoff of 700 eV and a denser K-sampling grid of 2 × 2 × 1. The Cu5/TiO2 structure is modeled by a three TiO2-layer slab with a planar Cu5 cluster adsorbed on. During the structural relaxation and the transition state search, the bottom TiO2 layer is fixed. For the electronic structure calculation, a larger cutoff energy of 700 eV and a denser K point grid of 2 × 2 × 1 sampling are adopted. Hubbard onsite energy correction (DFT + U) is considered in the electronic structure calculation. The values of U = 4.2 eV, 5.2 eV are chosen for Ti and Cu respectively, and the values of J are set to 0 eV form both elements. These U and J values have been used in previous work and have given consistent results with experiments and hybrid function calculations. [22,23,29]The DFT-D3 dispersion correction scheme by Grimme[30] is employed in all the calculations. The reaction mechanism is studied by analyzing the free energy landscape of different reaction pathways. To this end, the Thermo Energy Correction is calculated for each species by using the VASPKIT interface[31] combined with the vibrational frequency calculation using VASP package. For the adsorbed molecules, all the 3 N degrees of freedom of the molecule are considered during the vibrational frequency calculations, while the contribution of the Cu5/TiO2 substrate is suppressed by fixing the atoms. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Atomic and electronic structure of Cu5/TiO2 The atomic structure of Cu5/TiO2 is illustrated in Fig. 1 . The surface of TiO2 contains four types of atoms: five-fold coordinated Ti (Ti5c) atoms, six-fold coordinated Ti (Ti6c) atoms, two-fold coordinated O (O2c) atoms, and three-fold coordinated O (O3c) atoms. According to our previous work[21], in the ground state the Cu5 cluster forms an inclined trapezoidal planar structure when bonded to the TiO2 surface, with the three Cu atoms at the bottom bonded to the two-fold coordinated O2c atoms in the same row respectively, while leaving the two Cu atoms at the top unbounded with any surface atom. The O2c and O3c on the surface can serve as active sites for binding H atoms, whereas both the Cu5 cluster and adjacent Ti5c can be utilized as binding sites for CO2, providing a location for CO2 hydrogenation. In order to activate and chemically adsorb the CO2 molecule, some electrons must transfer from the substrate to the CO2 molecule in order to break the strong C=O bond. Therefore, the adsorption site should be electron-rich. As depicted in Fig. 1(b) and (d), the calculated differential electron density clearly indicates that electrons primarily accumulate within the area between the top Cu atoms and the nearby surface Ti5c atoms. This suggests that the top two Cu atoms are likely to serve as the main active sites for CO2 adsorption and hydrogenation. 3.2 CO2 adsorption on Cu5/TiO2 Before hydrogenation, the CO2 molecule should first adsorb on the Cu5/TiO2 substrate. Therefore, we begin by determining the most probable adsorption configuration of CO2. Our calculations have revealed four possible adsorption configurations, as depicted in Fig. 2 : top-bent, top-linear, side-bent, and Ti5c-linear. The corresponding adsorption energies (without thermo energy correction) are −0.14 eV, −0.45 eV, −0.16 eV, and −0.37 eV respectively. After considering the thermo energy correction, the adsorption energies are −0.21 eV, −0.51 eV, −0.23 eV and −0.43 eV for different configurations. The top-linear configuration is found to be energetically most favorable. In the case of two linear adsorption configurations, the Cu-OCO2 and Ti-OCO2 distances are 2.19 Å and 2.59 Å, respectively, indicating chemical adsorption of CO2 molecule in these cases as well. When comparing the adsorption at Ti5c site with that on pure TiO2 surface, it was observed that the calculated adsorption energy is reduced by 0.08 eV in presence of Cu5 clusters. This suggests that the presence of Cu5 cluster facilitates the adsorption of CO2 on the Ti5c site as well. The differential electron density reveals distinct bonding properties for different adsorption configurations. As depicted in Fig. 2, in the top-bent and side-bent adsorption configurations, electrons are transferred from the top two Cu atoms to the CO2 molecule and accumulate within the center of the Cu-OCO2 and Cu-C bonds. The electron densities located at the center of C=O bonds significantly decrease, indicating a notable weakening of the C=O covalent bonds. This weakening is crucial for the subsequent reduction process of CO2. Conversely, in the two linear adsorption configurations, a decrease in electron density is observed on the Cu and Ti5c atoms, as well as on the C and terminal O atom. The transferred electrons mainly gather around the O atom bonded with the metal atom. The electron densities located at the center of distal C=O bond show no significant change, suggesting that there is no substantial influence on the strength of this bond. Therefore, based on differential electron density analysis, it can be speculated that although bent adsorption is energetically less favored compared to linear adsorption, it more effectively facilitates CO2 reduction than linear adsorption. Since the bent adsorption configurations of CO2 exhibit higher activity than the linear adsorption configurations, it is possible for the *CO2 in linear adsorption configuration to undergo a transformation into the bent adsorption configuration during the reduction reaction process, thereby reducing the reaction barrier. Transition barriers from the top-linear configuration to both top-bent and side-bent configurations, as well as from the Ti5c-linear configuration to both top-linear and side-bent configurations, were calculated using CI-NEB and Dimer methods. The energy curves of these transitions are depicted in Fig. 3 . It can be observed that the transition energy barrier from the top-linear configuration to either top-bent or side-bent configuration is only ∼0.3 eV, indicating a feasible transfer from top-linear to top-bent configuration during reduction reaction. Furthermore, with a transition energy barrier of only 0.09 eV, it is evident that the Ti5c-linear configuration is dynamically unstable and may transfer to the top-linear configuration during reduction reaction. 3.3 H2 dissociation and H migration on Cu5/TiO2 We consider four possible active sites for H2 adsorption: top Cu atoms (site A), bottom Cu atoms (site B), Ti5c atoms (site C), and O2c atoms on the substrate (site D) as shown in Fig. 4 (a). The calculated adsorption energies of H2 are −0.38 eV for site A, −0.21 eV for site B, −0.20 eV for site C, and −0.12 eV for site D respectively. The dissociation barriers of H2 on different sites are 0.36 eV for site A, 0.38 eV for site B, 1.13 eV for site C and 2.15 eV for site D as shown in Fig. 4(b). According to our calculations, H2 prefers to adsorb on the top-Cu atoms of Cu5 cluster and can be easily dissociated which is consistent with previous studies [32]. For the most stable adsorption cases, after dissociation two protons adsorb on the top-Cu atom and O2c atom of the substrate respectively, as shown in Fig. 4(c). Based on this configuration, we then study the migration behavior of *H. For the *H adsorbed at the O2c site, it has the potential to migrate to nearby O3c sites and then from the O3c sites to other O2c sites (Path A as depicted in Fig. 5 (a)). The *H at the O2c site must overcome a barrier of approximately 0.76 eV in order to migrate to the nearby O3c site, and subsequently surpass a barrier of about 0.35 eV from the O3c site to the other O2c site, as illustrated in Fig. 5(b). In fact, there are four possible migration pathways for *H from its initial position at the O2c site to neighboring O2c sites. According to our calculations, their migration barriers are similar. The moderate kinetic barrier suggests that migration of *H on the TiO2 surface is relatively facile. For the *H adsorbed at the top-Cu site, it may migrate to the nearby O2c site of the substrate or between different sites on the Cu5 cluster, as illustrated by Path B and Path C in Fig. 5(a) respectively. In Path B, depicted in Fig. 5(c), the forward barrier from the original state to the metastable state is 0.96 eV, and that from the metastable state to the final state is 0.60 eV. However, there is almost no barrier for transition from the metastable state to the original state. For Path C, as shown in Fig. 5(d), the forward and backward migration barriers are 0.54 eV and 0.84 eV respectively. Therefore, *H at the top-Cu site prefers migrating between different sites of Cu5 cluster rather than migrating to the substrate. 3.4 Mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation CO2 can be transformed into various products through one-site hydrogenation reactions, such as CH3OH and CH4. In the case of CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH, two reaction mechanisms have been proposed. The first mechanism is known as the RWGS pathway, in which *CO2 is initially reduced to *CO via a reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction pathway, and then further hydrogenated into methanol. The second mechanism is called the formate pathway, where *CO2 is first hydronated into the HCOO* intermediate followed by further hydrogenation and dissociation into methanol. [33] The preference for a particular mechanism depends on the catalyst. Previous studies have shown that the Formate pathway is more effective than the RWGS pathway at interfaces such as ZnO/Cu [34] and Zn/Cu, [35] as well as with catalysts like ZrO2-supported In2O3, [36] CeO2-supported PdZn, [37] Fe3 and Ru3 clusters anchored on the MoS2 substrate [38], However, for other catalysts such as Cu/TiO2 and Cu/ZrO2 [39], Pd7 and Pd9 clusters [40], atomically thin CuIn5S8 layers [41], graphene supported Ni single atom [42], etc., the RWGS mechanism is favored. Our calculations consider both mechanisms to determine their respective preferences. 3.4.1 RWGS mechanism (1) Hydrogenation of CO2 to CO As previously discussed, among the four adsorption configurations of *CO2, the top-bent configuration is expected to be the most active and can be easily hydrogenated by the *H adsorbed at the O2c site. Therefore, we will first study the hydrogenation process of this configuration. As depicted in Fig. 6 (a), as anticipated, the *CO2 in top-bent configuration can be readily hydrogenated by the initial *H due to the presence of a hydrogen bond between *CO2 and *H, resulting in an activation barrier of only 0.02 eV. Subsequently, *COOH undergoes further hydrogenation into *CO and *H2O, overcoming an energy barrier of 0.28 eV. Finally, the H2O molecule desorbs from the surface, leaving behind a CO molecule adsorbed on the Cu cluster. For the top-linear configuration, the C=O bond of *CO2 is almost unaffected by adsorption, and the distal O of *CO2 is slightly distant from the nearby *H at the O2c site, making direct hydrogenation of the distal O difficult. In order to be hydrogenated, the linear-structural *CO2 must rotate towards the non-bonded top Cu atom and then be hydrogenated by the nearby *H, as illustrated in Fig. 6(b). The energy barrier for this hydrogenation step is 0.32 eV. The atomic structure of the resulting *COOH is identical to that of the hydrogenation product in a top-bent configuration. Further hydrogenation of *COOH follows a similar process as that in a top-bent configuration. Additionally, it is possible for *CO2 in a top-linear configuration to first transform into a top-bent configuration before undergoing hydrogenation, as the transition barrier from top-linear to top-bent configuration is nearly equivalent to direct hydrogenation barrier. In the side-bent configuration, *CO2 can be hydrogenated to *COOH by the *H adsorbed at the O2c site, overcoming an energy barrier of 0.55 eV (Fig. 6(c)). However, the activation barrier for this process is much larger than the transition from the side-bent configuration to the top-linear configuration, which has almost no barrier. Therefore, direct hydrogenation of *CO2 in the side-bent configuration is unlikely to occur. It will likely transform into the top-linear configuration before undergoing hydrogenation reaction. For the Ti5c-linear configuration, although the distance between *CO2 and *H is close, direct hydrogenation is not feasible due to the strong C=O bond in the linear structure. The activation of the linear *CO2 into a bent structure must occur prior to hydrogenation. The activation barrier from the linear structure to the bent structure is 0.53 eV, as depicted in Fig. 6(d), which exceeds the desorption barrier of *CO2 in the Ti5c-linear configuration. Consequently, hydrogenation of *CO2 in this configuration is also unattainable. Furthermore, transformation of *CO2 in the Ti5c-linear configuration to top-linear configuration should take place before hydrogenation due to a much lower transition barrier as discussed earlier. Overall, the detailed discussions above indicate that the *CO2 adsorbed on the Cu5/TiO2 surface can be readily hydrogenated into *CO. In order to form methanol or other fuel molecules, further hydrogenation of *CO is necessary, making the stability of *CO crucial for subsequent hydrogenation reactions. As depicted in Fig. 6(a), the desorption barrier of the *CO is as high as 1.18 eV, which enables the hydrogenation of *CO. (2) Hydrogenation of CO to CH3OH The hydrogenation process of *CO to CH3OH is illustrated in Fig. 7 . The rate-determining step is the initial hydrogenation step (*CO+*H→*CHO), with a transition energy barrier of 0.94 eV, which is smaller than the desorption barrier of *CO, allowing for the hydrogenation of *CO under appropriate conditions. Subsequently, in order to accept the second proton, the *CHO rotates about 90° on the axis of Cu-C bond, causing O to bond with the other top Cu. This step is exothermic and barrierless, facilitating easy rotation of *CHO. Then, the C atom undergoes hydrogenation by the second proton at the same O2c site as the first one, forming a *CH2O structure with a barrier of 0.28 eV. We also considered the possibility of hydrogenating the O atom by placing a proton on a nearby O2c site for the second hydrogenation step. However, our calculation indicates that this reaction cannot occur. For the third hydrogenation step, both carbon (C) and oxygen (O) can potentially undergo hydrogenation. When C is hydrogenated, *CH3O is formed by overcoming an energy barrier of 0.19 eV. Subsequently, *CH3O can be easily further hydrogenated into *CH3OH without encountering an energy barrier. On the other hand, the hydrogenation of the O atom in *CH2O to form *CH2OH is nearly barrierless, while the formation of *CH3OH from *CH2OH requires overcoming an energy barrier of 0.06 eV. Therefore, both pathways are feasible for this process. It is widely recognized that the formation of CH3OH and CH4 are typically competitive during the hydrogenation reaction of CO2. Therefore, it is important to also consider the formation of CH4. In order to produce CH4, the O atom of the intermediate *CH2OH must be hydrogenated rather than the C atom. As depicted in Fig. 7, the transition energy barrier for this reaction is as high as 1.94 eV. Thus, it is evident that the reaction will favor the pathway leading to the formation of CH3OH rather than CH4. 3.4.2 Formate mechanism For the formate mechanism, the initial hydrogenation should occur on carbon rather than oxygen. Let us first consider the top-bent adsorption configuration of *CO2. As depicted in Fig. 8 , since the carbon atom of *CO2 is distant from the O2c site, it can only be hydrogenated by the proton adsorbed on the Cu5 cluster, which is energetically less stable compared to that adsorbed on the O2c site. Additionally, the activation barrier for the hydrogenation of carbon is 0.13 eV, slightly higher than that for the hydrogenation of oxygen by a proton at the O2c site. Therefore, it may be inferred that top-bent *CO2 tends to favor the RWGS pathway. Furthermore, if the hydrogenation of C occurs, the resulting reaction product *CHOO is highly stable. This stability poses a significant challenge for the subsequent hydrogenation reaction (*CHOO+*H→*CHOOH), as the forward barrier is 1.10 eV while the reverse reaction barrier is only 0.25 eV. Consequently, it is nearly impossible for top-bent *CO2 to form methanol through the formate pathway. For the top-linear *CO2, the distance between the C atom and the *H adsorbed on the nearby O2c site is appropriate. However, due to the strong C-O bond of the linear structure, hydrogenation of C is challenging. As shown in Fig. 8, the energy barriers for both forward and backward reactions of the first hydrogenation step are 1.12 eV and 0.82 eV, respectively. The forward reaction barrier is significantly higher than the desorption barrier of top-linear *CO2, making it nearly impossible to reduce top-linear *CO2 into methanol through the formate pathway. This holds true for both Ti5c-linear and side-bent configurations as well, where activation energy barriers for hydrogenation of C are 0.83 eV and 0.80 eV, respectively—both much higher than desorption barriers of *CO2—resulting in desorption from substrate before this reaction occurs. Overall, based on our calculations, Cu5/TiO2 demonstrates outstanding catalytic performance in the reduction of CO2. The *CO2 adsorbed on Cu5/TiO2 can undergo hydrogenation to produce methanol through the RWGS pathway, exhibiting high selectivity. 4 Conclusion In summary, the catalytic reduction mechanism of CO2 on TiO2-supported Cu5 clusters has been extensively studied through thermodynamic and kinetic calculations using the DFT method. The adsorption of CO2 on Cu5/TiO2 was the initial focus of investigation. It was observed that CO2 can chemically adsorb onto the Cu5 cluster in both bent (top-bent and side-bent) and linear structures (top-linear), or it can adsorb onto the nearby Ti5c atom of the TiO2 substrate in a linear structure (linear-Ti5c). The top-linear configuration was found to be energetically and dynamically the most stable. Additionally, it was noted that other adsorption configurations could easily transition into the top-linear configuration by overcoming very low energy barriers. The dissociation of H2 and the migration of so-formed *H on Cu5/TiO2 are also investigated in this study. It is observed that H2 can be readily dissociated at the top-Cu site, resulting in the adsorption of two protons on the top-Cu and O2c atoms, respectively. The *H adsorbed at the O2c site demonstrates the ability to transfer to other O2c sites by overcoming moderate energy barriers, while that adsorbed on the Cu atom can easily migrate between different sites of Cu5 cluster. These findings suggest that H2 can serve as a proton source for the hydrogenation reaction of CO2. The catalytic reduction mechanisms of CO2 on Cu5/TiO2 to C1 products are investigated in this study. It is observed that *CO can be selectively hydrogenated into CH3OH following the RWGS mechanism. The top-bent adsorption configuration proves to be most beneficial for CO2 reduction, as the first-step hydrogenation of *CO2 in this configuration is nearly barrierless, facilitating easy reduction into *CO. The rate-determining barrier from the top-bent *CO2 to *CO is found to be as low as 0.28 eV. Additionally, it is noted that the top-linear *CO2 can also undergo hydrogenation by transferring to a top-bent-like structure with an energy barrier of approximately 0.3 eV. During the reaction, both side-bent and Ti5c-linear configurations of *CO2 will transfer into the top-linear configuration before undergoing hydrogenation. The bonding of Cu5/TiO2 to *CO is identified as quite strong, ensuring further hydrogenation into other hydrocarbon products such as CH3OH. Furthermore, it is determined that the first hydrogenation step in converting *CO into CH3OH serves as the rate-determining step with an energy barrier of 0.94 eV. In contrast, due to its much higher energy barrier (1.94 eV), the formation of CH4 from *CO appears almost impossible when compared to the formation of CH3OH. coredata.dc:description: Copper clusters supported on TiO2 have demonstrated exceptional performance in catalyzing the reduction of CO2. However, there is a lack of detailed studies on the underlying mechanism. In this study, we employ first-principles thermodynamics and kinetic calculations to unveil the catalytic reduction mechanism of CO2 to C1 product on the Cu5/TiO2 catalyst. Our calculations reveal that the interaction between the cluster and the support significantly enhances the chemical adsorption of CO2 and lowers the dissociation barrier of H2, creating favorable conditions for hydrogenation reduction of CO2. Additionally, our findings suggest that the Cu5 cluster also significantly enhances the adsorption of *CO intermediates, resulting in a preference for the RWGS pathway over the formate pathway for CO2 reduction. The rate-determining barrier for CH3OH formation is considerably lower than that for CH4 formation, indicating that Cu5/TiO2 exhibits remarkable CO2 conversion performance with nearly 100 % selectivity towards CH3OH production.
